lines.text: You see... I don't leave my diamonds in the soap dish... and when the time comes when nobody desires me... for myself... I'd rather not be... desired... at all.
Rome is a very old city. Three-thousand years. How old are you? Fifty?
Isn't it odd how women of our age, suddenly start looking for beauty in our male partners? But, I suppose after you've been married to that elderly invalid for 20 years...
I loved Tom Stone.
Oh, did you? Everyone thought you married him to avoid...
What?
Love. I think you depended on him. But, that's different. Anyway, now he's dead, what have you got to fall back on, except for his filthy millions?

Of all the people in Italy, why did you have to pick on that bunch? Oh, the young ones are pretty, of course, and I'm told they make love very nicely. But, is that enough to ask of a whole human society?
Is this yourself? Or, rather, what you've become. A figure of fun. The stock character of a middle aged woman, crazily infatuated with a succession of young boys!
Paolo, why have you done nothing but...
Please, I have a terrible headache.
And you can't stay tonight? That's it, isn't it! But, not because of any headache. It's because you made a date with that cheap little...
Cheap is not a word, I think, that you should use.

Your friend, the Contessa, is nothing but a female pimper with a stable of handsome boys she sells to the highest bidder. I won't deal in that ugly traffic. And so she passes you on to someone who will!
I had no idea your mind was such a cess pool.
My God, what's happened to Karin Stone?
Yes, isn't it strange?
She used to be so wonderful.
Well, you know the time comes when Mother Nature catches up with all you old gals.
Oh, come now, she can't be that old.
Oh, she's forty-five.
And then some.
Do you want to talk about it?
There's really nothing to say; except, I should have learned my lesson the first time I tried to play Shakespeare.
Believe me, Paulo, nothing touches me more deeply than human loneliness. The first time I met Signora Stone, almost a year ago, I could hardly stop myself from weeping.
I think its bad to be alone, so much.
I know.
It makes you sad.
It makes you drift.
Drift?
Yes, drift.
Like a flower on a river.
When I told you I was drifting, did you understand?
Not why it made you sad. I too am drifting, Signora. The whole world, everybody, the stars, everything is drifting. Is it so bad to drift? Is it so unhappy?
Yes, when you have no where to go.
Your hand's a fist. Open it. Give it to me.
Oh, Karen, there isn't anybody who ever knew you and who ever loved you...
Who are these people who love me? I want names.
I can give you thousands. You represented...
Various parts. Parts in the theater. Never, ever, myself.
Do you know her?
She's not for you. She only does it for money.
Listen, Paolo, there's no such thing as a great American lady. Great ladies do not occur in a nation less than 200 years old.
It's such a thrill to meet you, even though I never saw you on the stage. Isn't that terrible?
Why not at all. I'm afraid I've never seen you on the screen.
You see, Contessa, Americans aren't as romantic as their motion pictures.
What a pity.
Did you see Meg before she left?
Meg? Where'd she go?
Oh, some place in the Middle East. She says its a big trouble spot.
I thought everywhere in the Middle East was a big trouble spot.
